t: Proverbs 18
An*pn unfriendly person pursues selfish ends and*ld against all sound judgment starts quarrels.
Fools*pn find no pleasure in understanding but*ld delight in airing their own opinions.
When*pn wickedness comes, so does contempt, and*ld with shame comes reproach.
The*pn words of the mouth are deep waters, but*ld the fountain of wisdom is a rushing stream.
It*pn is not good to be partial to the wicked and*ld so deprive the innocent of justice.
The*pn lips of fools bring them strife, and*ld their mouths invite a beating.
The*pn mouths of fools are their undoing, and*ld their lips are a snare to their very lives.
The*pn words of a gossip are like choice morsels; they*ld go down to the inmost parts.
One*pn who is slack in his work is*ld brother to one who destroys.
The*pn name of the Lord*s is a fortified tower; the*ld righteous run to it and are safe.
The*pn wealth of the rich is their fortified city; they*ld imagine it a wall too high to scale.
Before*pn a downfall the heart is haughty, but*ld humility comes before honor.
To*pn answer before listening— that*ld is folly and shame.
The*pn human spirit can endure in sickness, but*ld a crushed spirit who can bear?
The*pn heart of the discerning acquires knowledge, for*ld the ears of the wise seek it out.
A*pn gift opens the way and*ld ushers the giver into the presence of the great.
In*pn a lawsuit the first to speak seems right, until*ld someone comes forward and cross-examines.
Casting*pn the lot settles disputes and*ld keeps strong opponents apart.
A*pn brother wronged is more unyielding than a fortified city; disputes*ld are like the barred gates of a citadel.
From*pn the fruit of their mouth a person’s stomach is filled; with*ld the harvest of their lips they are satisfied.
The*pn tongue has the power of life and death, and*ld those who love it will eat its fruit.
He*pn who finds a wife finds what is good and*ld receives favor from the Lord.*s
The*pn poor plead for mercy, but*ld the rich answer harshly.
One*pn who has unreliable friends soon comes to ruin, but*ld there is a friend who sticks closer than a brother.
